titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Douglas P. Murray papers FA1122

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2025-01-01 06:06:10 UTC.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: National Committee on United States-China Relations

physdesc.extent: 29 letter document boxes, 5 legal document boxes and 1 half-letter document box.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Douglas P. Murray attended Yale University where he received his BA in Behavioral Science in 1958 and his MA in Southeast Asian Studies in 1961. He went on to receive his PhD in International Development Education from Stanford University, with his dissertation on Chinese education in Singapore.

Throughout his career he has held several positions related to Asia and China: Director of the US-China Relations Program at Stanford University, 1975-1981, Vice President of the East-West Center in Honolulu, 1981-1984, Executive Secretary of the Committee on International Relations Studies with the People's Republic of China, and President of China Institute in America, 1986-1988.

He first traveled to Asia in 1958 to teach English at New Asia College, Hong Kong, through the Yale-China Association, and has taught at New Zealand's Victoria University and in Singapore while serving as Representative of The Asia Foundation.

He joined the National Committee on United States-China Relations first as Program Director and Vice President, 1975-1981, and has served as a member of its Board and Executive Committee. He was President of NCUSCR in 1997.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into 3 series: Series 1-National Committee on United States-China Relations (NCUSCR), Administrative Series 2-National Committee on United States-China Relations (NCUSCR), Environmental Programs Series 3-Committee on International Relations Studies with the People's Republic of China (CIRSPRC)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Types of records include: correspondence, travel logs, brochures and pamphlets, photographs, and newspaper articles.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Rockefeller Archive Center has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them, and has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Collection was donated to Rockefeller Archive Center by Douglas P. Murrary in 2015.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Rockefeller Archive Center has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them, and has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection.
